bibl.idno: The Philip S. Hench Walter Reed/Yellow Fever Collection [manuscript] / [collected by] Philip S. Hench ; HEALTHSCI MS-1.

div1.p: [Carter] writes corrections for another person's manuscript concerning yellow fever and dengue.

div1.head: Memorandum by [Henry Rose Carter], June 16, 1923
div1.p:
Miss
Service
(brushing)
/LC
2121 California St., N. W.
Washington, D. C.,
June 16, 1923.

2)--Page 33b: “a period of about twelve days”--“about” is necessary as
the minimum of extrinsic incubation of yellow fever cannot be cer-
tainly predicated.

3)-Page 33b: On what evidence does this assertion rest? I only ask the
the question because I do not recall any.

4)--Page 33c: This is absolutely correct as an argument, but would it not
be somewhat more impressive if you arranged the script a little dif-
ferently?--e. g.

"The person infected with dengue------yellow fever patient be-
cause:
"(1) The latter is infective----up to eight days.

"(2) The yellow fever patient---or net: in dengue if mild the
patient-----about and even in more severe cases----remission.

“With only the same vector then dengue would obviously spread
much more rapidly than yellow fever and the writer would not be
willing to assume the existence of other vectors simply to explain
this greater rapidity of spread.”

This, you see, is no change, but is possibly more apt to catch
the eye of the reader than your arrangement.
